# GitHub Push Guide for Large Files

## Quick Commands

### Standard Push (for files < 100MB)
```bash
# Initialize git (if not already done)
git init

# Add all files
git add .

# Commit
git commit -m "Initial commit: Tradyx Options Dashboard"

# Add remote (replace with your repo URL)
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/YOUR_REPO.git

# Push to GitHub
git push -u origin main
```

## Handling Large Files

### Option 1: Exclude Large Files (Recommended)

**Update `.gitignore` to exclude:**
```
# Data files (regenerated by scripts)
data/
scripts/data/
public/data/dashboard.json

# Build artifacts
.next/
out/
dist/
build/

# Dependencies
node_modules/
*.log

# Python
__pycache__/
*.pyc
*.pyo
*.pyd
.Python
*.so
*.egg
*.egg-info/
.mypy_cache/
.pytest_cache/

# IDE
.vscode/
.idea/
*.swp
*.swo

# OS
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db
```

Then push:
```bash
git add .
git commit -m "Add project files"
git push -u origin main
```

### Option 2: Use Git LFS for Large Files (if needed)

**For files > 100MB, use Git LFS:**

```bash
# Install Git LFS (if not installed)
# Windows: Download from https://git-lfs.github.com/
# Or: winget install Git.Git-LFS

# Initialize Git LFS
git lfs install

# Track large files
git lfs track "*.json"
git lfs track "data/**"
git lfs track "scripts/data/**"

# Add .gitattributes (created by lfs track)
git add .gitattributes

# Add and commit
git add .
git commit -m "Add project with LFS for large files"
git push -u origin main
```

### Option 3: Split Large Files

If you have very large files (> 1GB), consider:
- Storing data files in a separate repository
- Using cloud storage (S3, Google Drive) and linking
- Compressing files before committing

## Complete Push Workflow

```bash
# 1. Check current status
git status

# 2. Add files (respects .gitignore)
git add .

# 3. Check what will be committed
git status

# 4. Commit
git commit -m "Your commit message"

# 5. Push to GitHub
git push -u origin main

# For subsequent pushes:
git add .
git commit -m "Update message"
git push
```

## Troubleshooting Large Files

### Error: "File too large"
```bash
# Remove large file from git history
git rm --cached large-file.json

# Add to .gitignore
echo "large-file.json" >> .gitignore

# Commit the removal
git commit -m "Remove large file"

# Push
git push
```

### Error: "Push rejected - large file"
```bash
# Use Git LFS or remove the file
# See Option 2 above
```

### Check File Sizes Before Pushing
```bash
# Windows PowerShell
Get-ChildItem -Recurse | Where-Object {$_.Length -gt 10MB} | Select-Object FullName, @{Name="Size(MB)";Expression={[math]::Round($_.Length/1MB,2)}}

# Or find large files
git ls-files | xargs ls -la | sort -k5 -rn | head -20
```

## Recommended .gitignore for This Project

Create/update `.gitignore`:

```gitignore
# Dependencies
node_modules/
.pnp
.pnp.js

# Testing
coverage/
*.log

# Next.js
.next/
out/
build/
dist/

# Production
*.production

# Misc
.DS_Store
*.pem
Thumbs.db

# Debug
npm-debug.log*
yarn-debug.log*
yarn-error.log*

# Local env files
.env
.env*.local
.env.production

# Vercel
.vercel

# TypeScript
*.tsbuildinfo
next-env.d.ts

# Python
__pycache__/
*.py[cod]
*$py.class
*.so
.Python
*.egg-info/
dist/
build/
.mypy_cache/
.pytest_cache/
.venv/
venv/

# Data files (regenerated by scripts)
data/
scripts/data/
public/data/dashboard.json
scripts/public/

# IDE
.vscode/
.idea/
*.swp
*.swo
*.sublime-project
*.sublime-workspace

# OS
.DS_Store
.DS_Store?
._*
.Spotlight-V100
.Trashes
ehthumbs.db
Thumbs.db
```

## Step-by-Step: First Time Push

```bash
# 1. Navigate to project root
cd "C:\Users\hp\Desktop\Desktop Placed\Tradyx\tradyx-options-dashboard"

# 2. Initialize git (if not done)
git init

# 3. Check/create .gitignore (see above)

# 4. Add remote repository
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/tradyx-options-dashboard.git

# 5. Add all files
git add .

# 6. Check what's being added (should NOT include node_modules, .next, data/)
git status

# 7. Commit
git commit -m "Initial commit: Tradyx Options Dashboard with production-grade data fetchers"

# 8. Push to GitHub
git push -u origin main

# If main branch doesn't exist, use:
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main
```

## For Large Repositories

If your repository is still too large even after .gitignore:

```bash
# Check repository size
du -sh .git

# Remove large files from history (use with caution!)
git filter-branch --force --index-filter \
  "git rm --cached --ignore-unmatch path/to/large-file" \
  --prune-empty --tag-name-filter cat -- --all

# Force push (WARNING: rewrites history)
git push origin --force --all
```

## Best Practices

1. **Never commit:**
   - `node_modules/` (use `npm install` on deployment)
   - `data/` files (regenerate with scripts)
   - `.next/` build folder
   - Large binary files

2. **Always commit:**
   - Source code (`.tsx`, `.ts`, `.py`)
   - Configuration files (`.json`, `.config.js`)
   - Documentation (`.md`)
   - `.gitignore`

3. **For data files:**
   - Keep scripts in repo
   - Add `data/` to `.gitignore`
   - Document how to generate data in README

## Quick Reference

```bash
# Standard workflow
git add .
git commit -m "Message"
git push

# Check what will be pushed
git status
git ls-files

# Remove file from git but keep locally
git rm --cached filename

# Check repository size
git count-objects -vH
```
